results.title: Adam and Eve
results.brief_description: An animated film using abstract cutouts, symbolising life, reproduction, growth and destruction from creation to the end of the world in an explosion, then the beginning of a new cycle.

results.title: The Magic Trumpet
results.creator_credit: Dusan Marek, Eltham Films and Anim-ad Films
results.brief_description: An experimental film using mainly animated paper cut-outs to tell the story of a magic trumpet which brings fame and fortune to an old tramp. Story script by Tim Burstall, music by Michael Kenny and montage, animation and photography by Dusan Marek.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dusan Marek, Eltham Films and Anim-ad Films

results.title: The Unfinished Dance
results.creator_credit: Henry Koster, Joe Pasternak and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Aspirational young ballet dancer refuses to let anything or anyone get in her way to becoming a prima ballerina. Cast includes Margaret O’Brien, Cyd Charisse, Karin Booth, Esther Dale, Thurston hall, harry hayden, Danny Thomas.

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film shows an example of life in Victoria, Australia, just prior to the Second World War. Much of it revolves around members of the Parsons family and friends who are clearly not camera shy. In a number of scenes, you can see individuals playing up to the camera. There is even a staged boxing match on the beach where Robin (George Robinson) Parsons experimented with using special effects.

The film shows several Victorian locations including Melbourne, Dromana, Rosebud Aerodrome, Cape Schanck, Mt Hotham, Mallacoota, Wangarrata and Yallourn. Dromana Beach is featured a few times and appears to be a family favourite for swimming and family gatherings.

This film is rich with fashion of the period, both casual and formal, including two weddings of different periods and golfing attire.

Included in the film is the 1935 centennial celebrations parade showing crowded street with brass bands travelling down Collins Street, including a brief scene of an Aboriginal float. Much of these scenes are taken from the rooftop of Parsons Bros and company building. The company would later form Uncle Toby’s.

The film also includes the Shrine of Remembrance, St Pauls cathedral, Princes Bridge and many other Melbourne landmarks including some buildings and sites that no longer exist.

Of interest are the many forms of transport that are seen throughout which include cars, trams, horses, bicycles, motor bike with side carriage, a canoe, bi planes, fighter planes, a gyrocopter, the Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane (only 12 were ever created), transport planes, steamboats, tugboats, a navy ship, locomotives and a Melbourne ferry.

Also of interest is a scene from the 1939 Australian Championship at Kooyong Stadium with John Bromwich and Adrian Quist.

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
This film is a continuation from Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 7

This film begins with the introduction of the Baining people. The Baining people are the original inhabitants of the Gazelle Peninsula of East New Britain. According to Albert Drayton the people had just been brought out from the mountains as part of the missionary work.

Numerous ceremonies are seen in this film including a wedding, dances, spear throwing and a mock battle.

The later part of the film is the return to Australia briefly visiting Brisbane and Sydney before returning to Melbourne.

Both deck quoits and deck tennis are seen being played on the ship.

There are scenes of the Sydney Harbour bridge, the Sydney Railway station and Town hall.

The film finishes with the Drayton family in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 – Missionary Grounds and local huts

00:00:31:00 – Footage of the Baining people with women weaving thread and stocking the fire

00:01:08:00 – Performances for the tourists including a marriage ceremony, Tower dance and spear throwing, a ceremonial dance, a mock battle and a victory dance

00:06:05:00 – Mt Drayton with one of the chiefs

00:06:09:00 – Performance with men wearing large decorative head gear supported with string controlled by the women

00:07:23:00 – Baining man with baby

00:07:36:00 – Masks and head pieces being given as a gift to the missionary cruise

00:08:15:00 – Cruise passengers packed into the ship deck on journey back from Papua New Guinea

00:08:48:00 – Cruise Passengers with the ship’s captain and Mr Dennis, the mayor of Northcote, Melbourne

00:09:18:00 – Passengers playing Quoits on the deck of the ship

00:10:11:00 – Views of Sydney Harbour Bridge with Harold Drayton and an Electric Train

00:10:45:00 – Sydney Central Railway Station and Town Hall with street view of traffic officer directing traffic

00:11:34:00 – Mavis, unidentified woman and Mrs Drayton

00:12:36:00 – Drayton family and passengers playing Deck Quoits and Tennis

00:13:26:00 – Albert Drayton and mother unpacking the car at Hampshire Road, Melbourne

00:13:35:00 - Mavis, unknown, Harold, Roy, Albert, unknown, Mrs Drayton (mother)

00:13:45:00 – Members of the Drayton family posing with gifts including Roy, Harold, Albert, Ted Drayton and Mother

00:14:34:00 – Peter (Mavis’s son) crawling to his aeroplane

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
This film follows on from the Drayton Family Movies: Reel 5

The film continues exploring events and scenes from Raboul in Papua New Guinea then continues to other villages.

There are many scenes of local people in costume providing performances and ceremonies for the tourists of the cruise ship.

There are a few scenes of missionary buildings and schools and many scenes of students in uniform. The student marching teams are seen doing regimented marching exercises.

Also seen are ruins and gravestones from early missionaries on the island.

Towards the end of the film a duk-duk dance is filmed. At the time it was an illegal dance to perform.

The film finishes at the arrival of another village in New Britain.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 – Young Chinese students, at the Overseas Chinese School, Raboul

00:00:09:00 – Harold Drayton, Mr Jefferies, Albert Drayton standing in a church doorway, Raboul

00:00:29:00 – Local Cemetery holding Australians soldiers killed in the First World War, Raboul

00:01:12:00 – Guards on Duty, Government House, Raboul

00:01:41:00 – Prisoners marching back to their cells after a day’s work, Raboul

00:01:51:00 – local costume and dance performance. George Brown College, Raboul

00:02:57:00 – College Boys in uniform marching, Raboul

00:03:22:00 – Harold Drayton, Mrs Drayton, Mr Drayton, Mrs Lowe, Mrs Hargraves part of the Sunshine cruise passengers drinking from coconuts

00:03:56:00 – Dance Performances and music, St George Browns College, Raboul

00:07:03:00 – George Brown College boys and girls, performing marching exercises, rhythm exercises with coconut shells and sticks, Raboul

00:09:40:00 – Passengers of the cruise on a hike with sun umbrellas, Raboul

00:09:56:00 – Man sitting on Tortoise as it tries to move, Raboul

00:11:12:00 – Cruise passengers posing with local men

00:11:14:00 – local man with spear and Axe

00:11:53:00 – local man performs a banned Duk-Duk-dance

00:13:45:00 – Farewelled by village locals, New Britain, boats point of view

00:14:26:00 – Arriving at a new village (unidentified) New Britain with local students in uniform and drums being played to welcome the tourists

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
Much of this film contains scenes of landscape in Alice Springs including the Standley Chasm.

There are a few different modes of transport seen throughout such as a 1956 Austin Healey, the Ghan locomotive, a bus owned by the Tuit’s coach services and horses.

Also shown is the John Flynn Memorial Church and Adelaide House, Alice Springs, the first hospital which was created by John Flynn.

Of interest for Aboriginal heritage is a few scenes of local Aboriginal men working on a tractor and Aboriginal horsemen.

The film finishes with a scene of the Drayton Home in Melbourne.

Selected hightlights list:
00:00:02:00 - Train carriage carrying a 1956 Austin Healey 100

00:00:12:00 – Old Ghan locomotive at the Old Ghan Heritage Railway and Museum Alice Springs

00:00:38:00 - Alice Springs, John Flynn Memorial Uniting Church

00:00:51:00 - Adelaide House, Alice Springs

00:00:59:00 – Two Aboriginal men working on a tractor

00:02:25:00 – Passengers exiting the bus – Tuit’s Coach Services

00:03:49:00 – Anzac Hill Memorial lookout - Alice Springs

00:05:10:00 – Scenic – Rocky hills on the way towards Standley Chasm, Alice Springs

00:06:57:00 – Standley Chasm

00:10:21:00 – Unknown saleswoman in a shop

00:10:25:00 – Cattle yard with cattle coming off a train carriage with 1954 Ford Mainline Utility in view

00:10:47:00 – tourists taking photos of Aboriginal horsemen

00:13:50:00 – Scenic reflection in a Puddle

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
This film follows the Drayton family on a Methodist missionary cruise to Papua New Guinea.

It begins in Sydney Harbour upon a passenger ship with a streamer farewell and continues with a visit to Stony Creek Falls and the Forest Gardens, Karunda before heading to Kwato and later Raboul, Papua New Guinea.

There are scenes of the Stony Creek train, bridge and falls as well as the Barron Falls.

In Kwato, there are many scenes of local men, women and children going about their daily activities including the making of Sago.

In Robaul, the tourists are treated to local celebration with music, costume and dance.

There a few scenes with boats, ships and canoes from Papa New Guinea including a canoe race.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 – Ship departure from Sydney dock with crowds and streamers

00:01:50:00 – Overflow Train and carriage Kuranda with Mr and Mrs Drayton and Ted Drayton

00:02:16:00 – Stony Creek Falls with tourists on the bridge and train. Stony Creek, Cairns

00:02:58:00 – Barron Falls, Cairns

00:03:34:00 – Mr and Mrs Drayton, unknown woman and Harold Drayton in the Rain Forest Gardens, Karanda

00:03:49:00 – Albert Drayton and sister Mavis in the Rain Forest Gardens, Karanda

00:06:18:00 – Jack Wallis, Mrs Drayton, Mr Webster and Mr Drayton, Kwato

results.description:
This film follows the Drayton family on a Methodist missionary cruise to Papua New Guinea.

It begins in Sydney Harbour upon a passenger ship with a streamer farewell and continues with a visit to Stony Creek Falls and the Forest Gardens, Karunda before heading to Kwato and later Raboul, Papua New Guinea.

There are scenes of the Stony Creek train, bridge and falls as well as the Barron Falls.

In Kwato, there are many scenes of local men, women and children going about their daily activities including the making of Sago.

In Robaul, the tourists are treated to local celebration with music, costume and dance.

There a few scenes with boats, ships and canoes from Papa New Guinea including a canoe race.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 – Ship departure from Sydney dock with crowds and streamers

00:01:50:00 – Overflow Train and carriage Kuranda with Mr and Mrs Drayton and Ted Drayton

00:02:16:00 – Stony Creek Falls with tourists on the bridge and train. Stony Creek, Cairns

00:02:58:00 – Barron Falls, Cairns

00:03:34:00 – Mr and Mrs Drayton, unknown woman and Harold Drayton in the Rain Forest Gardens, Karanda

00:03:49:00 – Albert Drayton and sister Mavis in the Rain Forest Gardens, Karanda

results.title: Farm Machinery Maintenance
results.creator_credit: Eric Thompson, Solarchrome and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: ‘Farm Machinery Maintenance’ is an instructional film made for the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, designed for an audience of farmers and agricultural workers. The film’s narrator outlines the importance of maintaining farm machinery and equipment to ensure their function and longevity. The film offers an interesting insight into farming methods of the 1950s, with footage of rural farms, machines and tools. As with many educational films of the era, the film displays a (now outdated) gender division of stereotypical roles for men and for women, with men operating the heavy machinery while women serve tea and pick fruit.

results.title: Hyper-Ballad
results.creator_credit: Firas Massouh, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Firas Massouh’s hunger for travel was started by his father who, as a communist activist, moved to Russia from Syria where he met his wife. With baby in tow, the family began a lifelong journey of travelling, which was continued by Firas when he decided to continue his father’s travels and move to Melbourne.
